title: CFD association says ASIC reforms could increase risks for investors
text:
ASIC’s proposed changes to the $11.5 trillion contracts for difference and binary options market could increase trading risks for local investors, the organisation representing derivative products says.

The Australian CFD and FX Association says reform plans by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission have failed to tackle unregulated and fraudulent local and offshore operators.

“Proposed restrictions may actually result in retail traders moving to these unlicensed brokers as traders seek more flexibility and leverage, causing more consumer harm,” association director Peta Stead said.

“It is the investor that should have the right to choose the products that they want to invest in.

“ASIC does not seem to recognise there are a significant number of retail investors who do fully understand the risks of CFDs and margin foreign exchange products but want to invest in them because of the potential short-term gains that are not present in most other products.”

ASIC is attempting to ban binary options and reduce leverage on CFDs to about 10 times, which is in line with best international practice, particularly in Asian markets.
description: Industry warns that proposed restrictions may result in retail traders moving across to unregulated local and offshore operators.
